div1.head: “The Tale of a Guinea Pig”, by John H. Andrus [1941]
div1.p:
T h e T a l e O f A G u i n e a P i g
By John H. Andrus.

With Dr. Carroll I entered the quarantined grounds of the
yellow fever hospital and stopped in front of one of the small
wards. Dr. Ames emerged with a hypodermic syringe in his hand.
Maybe my voice was not quite steady when I asked, “How is Dr
Forbes, Doctor?” Dr. Ames grinned, “You are not worrying
about Forbes, you're worried about Andrus.” He was probably
right. Entirely aside from my friendly interest in Forbes,
it would have bucked up my waning courage to have been told
that he was out of danger.

Forbes was at the height of a pronounced case of yellow
fever. He had been inoculated with the disease by the injec-
tion of one-half cubic centimeter of blood taken from a case,
acquired naturally, that had proven fatal. The hypodermic a
syringe in Dr. Ames' hand contained one cubic centimeter of
Forbes' blood taken but a moment before.

Dr. Ames scrubbed a place on my arm with antiseptic and I watched with fas-
cination as he inserted the needle and slowly pressed the plun-
ger. I knew that, from that instant, nothing could prevent
my having yellow fever. I knew that my inoculation would
cause me more pain and place my life in far greater jeopardy
than the bite of a rattlesnake. I glanced at Dr. Carroll.
His had been the first experimental infection - five months
before - and he was still far from recovered. As a Hospital
Corps man I had nursed yellow fever patients; I had seen men
writhing in pain and heard them babbling in delerium and I had
seen yellow fever deaths. With that needle buried in my arm
2
it was too late for heavy thinking. The shrug that accompan-
ied this conclusion brought a sharp twinge in my arm and an
even sharper admonition from Dr. Ames.

I was inoculated at 12:15 p.m. Jan 25, 1901. Six days
later Major Walter Reed, in a letter to the Surgeon-General of
the Army, George M. Sternberg, wrote of my case:

“... I am very uneasy about the non-immune soldier
who got the same amount of blood at the same time”
(as four mosquito-made immunes). “He seems to have
acquired a very serious infection, his temperature
running along the 104° line now for three days ...
Should he die I shall regret that I ever undertook
this work. The responsibility for the life of a
human being weighs upon me very heavily just at
present and I am dreadfully melancholic. Every-
thing is being done for him that we know how to do.” *

To go back to Dr. Ames - as he withdrew the needle and gave
my arm a final rub with antiseptic he said, “Too bad it's
Forbes' blood you are getting.” Visions of some otherbhor-
rible disease flashed in my mind as I asked, “Why, Doctor?”
“Well”, he replied, “you know how Forbes talks - don't be sur-
prised if you start talking the same way”. In the larger
affairs of the moment I laughed, promised Drs. Ames and Car-
roll that I would be back and stepped into the waiting ambu-
lance to be driven to Camp Lazear.
* Extract from page 227, Biography of General Sternberg.

Camp Lazear, a little more than a mile from Columbia Bar-
racks, was in an isolated open field. It consisted of two
small buildings, a large mess tent and seven small tents for
use as quarters. There was a permanent staff of three or
four immunes who served as cook, ambulance driver, etc. The
main purpose of the camp was to isolate volunteers for inoc-
ulation from any possibility of contact with yellow fever
except experimental. I was am the only volunteer for inoculation,
after the camp was established who was not quarantined there
for approximately two weeks before infection.

There, too, most of the inoculations were performed and -
as in my case - infected volunteers were held there, under
observation, until they became sick. Upon my arrival I was
assigned to a tent and was at liberty to go where I pleased,
within the camp, while the “bugs” with which I had been infec-
ted set up housekeeping and raised families in my blood stream.

One of the first things I did was to write home. I told
my mother that I had been detailed to accompany a troop of the
Seventh Cavalry on a practice march into the interior of the
Island. and would not be able to write again for two or three
weeks. I didn't feel too good about this. I wanted to leave
things so that the folks at home would not worry when they did
not hear from me for a while and that was the most reasonable
explanation that occurred to me. I did not like the idea of
lieing in my letter for I realized that it might be the last
letter I would ever write home.

And now, with time on my hands, I thought of what Dr. Ames
had told me about my talking the way Forbes did. He stammered
so badly that he was utterly unable to express himself until
4
he was able to invoke, “S-s-s-say, n-n-n-now l-l-l-lad”, and
then he was able to speak a few words almost normally. Was
it true that, by having some of his blood injected into me, I
might acquire the same impediment? That shows how young I
was. I was almost certain that Dr. Ames had been “kidding”
me but there was enough uncertainty so that, with little ef-
fort, I could worry about my predicament. If yellow fever
did not kill me I might have to go through life “Say, now
lading”.

Time passed slowly. I knew, from what I had heard of prev-
ious experimental cases, that there was a wide variation in
the time between inoculation and the chill that heralds the
disease. Perhaps I have over-emphasized worry. The food
at Camp Lazear was very much better than we were accustomed
to at the barracks and I did not worry enough to impair my
appetite. I had a bad quarter-hour, however, when I learned
that Dr. Ames was sick and, himself, in the hospital. He had
doctored all the experimental cases and had lost but one -
Dr. Lazear - in whose honor this camp was named.

At 1:15 p.m. Jan 28 - just three days and one hour after my
inoculation - the chill I had been waiting for arrived. At
first I thought my imagination was playing tricks on me for,
at noon, my temperature and pulse had been normal and I had
enjoyed my dinner. At three o'clock I decided that my imag-
ination had never been quite that vivid and suggested that my
temperature be taken. I was ordered to lie down on my bed
and the waiting ambulance was called. I am not at all clear
about the happenings of the next few days. I remember being
5
enraged because they insisted on carrying me to the ambulance
on a litter. They wouldn't even allow me to sit up. But I
soon lost interest in all such affairs. My legs, back and
arms seemed of immense size and bursting with pain. My back
arched, my legs and neck drew back - back - back and I dazedly
wondered whether all the pain was because of the abnormal
position or whether - if I could bend still farther - it would
ease the pain.

And no mile was ever so far. It seemed that those fast-
trotting Army mules had been on the way for weeks. I don't
remember reaching the hospital.
